content: So running a validation node is only going to pay around 7% per year?

author: pietjepuk
content: Depends on how many people are willing to stake their ETH. Can go down much more, e.g. to 4-5 %.  Note that this number excludes any possible transaction rewards/MEV.

author: potuz
content: Is there a C++ implementation of SSZ? I can find only https://github.com/NAKsir-melody/cpp_ssz but that seems to be dead

author: protolambda
content:
<@755590043632140352> you can find a list of implementations here: https://github.com/ethereum/eth2.0-specs/issues/2138
That c++ one was on older versions of the list, but long dead

author: potuz
content: Thanks, I figured it's simple enough to implement serialization on each one of my objects, that it makes sense to do it in-project than to have a separate project and have to pass it each object.

author: protolambda
content: <@755590043632140352> I took a similar approach in ZTYP (typing of ZRNT). Write helper functions to easily implement SSZ per type. That's for the flat struct/slice data though. I also have a 2nd typing system with typedefs/views/trees. The higher the data structure complexity, the more likely you want to generalize more.

author: potuz
content: Perfect, I'm following that approach so far. Adding a `serialize()` method to composite objects. I haven't dealt yet with hashing, when I get there will check if this design decision hurts me or not.
